 How would you propose to look for supernatural evidence that is not subjective?
 
 By definition, it could not be perceived by any of our physical senses. If there is any physical evidence of any sort, then the supernatural is no longer supernatural. So, we would have to 'look' beyond the physical into the metaphysical. Is there anyway to do this objectively without being subject to perceptions of the individual mind? It may be possible -- but how do you propose we do so?
sinjin

Assuming "evidence" could be supernatural. I see "supernatural" as akin to "spiritual" in that neither term has any objective reality whatsoever. Thus far all supernatural phenomenon thoroughly investigated have proven to be "natural" phenomena previously not fully understood or pure superstition and hoax.

and if that "as-of-yet unmeasurable physical force" is caused by God, spirits, or some other supernatural agent, would that make the event any more natural? if by some unseen force that i posses, i was able to [pick any comicbook hero ability], and it could be observed, would that make it less supernatural?

 
 Yes, it would make it not supernatural :/
 Sucks in a way, doesn't it? It would maybe be more fun if contracitions were possible, but they don't seem to be. I'd like TK powers btw.
 
 What's missing is the definition of natural. The word is based on a foundation of knowledge, which accepts the observable world around us, and the laws we have observed it follows, etc. This is then our definition of "nature" in terms of what is natural, and what is supernatural, is essentially a "negative quality", which is irrational to claim things about.
 
 If those foundations were to change, assuming the universe COULD actually "change" (I haven't thought about it either way), the old definitions would no longer be complete, and new definitions of what is "natural" would be required that encompass the new and the old, and then saying "supernatural" is again, not possible, since obviously it's observable, and consistent, within the framework of the universe, for such change to occur. Same with God, since it's not based on observation, a "real" god appearing couldn't prove the ficticious god existed, if it were not the basis for the claim in the first place. 
 
 It's like a tapestry, our knowledge is woven into the fabric of the Universe, so it's only consistent within that fabric.
 
 I was dismayed at first by this logic, but I've gotten to see it more clearly now, and not surprising, it is consistent, makes a sense, and is quite profound. 
 
 -Mach

 That's correct. They would all, by definition, be "not supernatural", or within the natural world. Supernatural, by definition, is a negative, "outside of human experience". If it's inside human experience, it's not supernatural. I realize this word, and many like it, are misused a lot (like say, X files).
 
 Something like you describe could "theoretically" occur, if, for instance, some ET had the ability to hide from our senses or affect our mind in such a way that we would no longer "observe". 
 But supernatural, being a negative (not natural), it cannot occur, by definition, in the natural universe. We can say "super-human", but not "super-natural". Or we say "super powers". And be consistent. So we can still enjoy some good old fashioned super hero battles, or a silverback gorilla hitting with "super human" strength, or an ET that can control energy and hurl flaming fireballs at you...but not the supernatural. The supernatural can still be portrayed in works of fiction that don't have to adhere to the sometimes boring, rational universe, I enjoy them there, personally.
 
 -Mach

 My point is not to be skeptical. My point is simply that whatever happened, happened. Believing that it actually happened or doubting that it happened does not change the reality of what happened. It may change your own perspective of reality, but belief is incapable of changing the reality of what actually happened. Does this make any sense?
 
 It is entirely conceivable that all the events are reported accurately, and this guy somehow was resurrected. It is also entirely conceivable that there is a very logical, reasonable explanation for the events of this guy's story. From a reasonable perspective, a true 'resurrection' is highly unlikely. From a perspective of faith, there need not be any reasonable explanation for the event to have actually occurred.
